statement.p: State the basic function and the transformations needed to graph ~~F(x)=5 \sqrt[3]{x}+6.

solution.p: The basic function is ~f(x)=\sqrt[3]{x}~. The output is multiplied by 5, and then 6 is added, so ~g(x)=5f(x)~, and ~F(x)=g(x)+6~.

statement.p: State the basic function and the transformations needed to graph ~~G(x)=\dfrac{-3}{(x-1)^2}.

solution.p: The basic function is ~f(x)=\dfrac{1}{x^2}~. We subtract 1 from the input, then multiply the output by -3, so ~g(x)=f(x-1)~, and ~G(x)=-3g(x)~.

statement.p: State the basic function and the transformations needed to graph ~~F(x)=\sqrt{x+6}+2.

answer.p: The basic function is ~f(x)=\sqrt{x}~. Then ~g(x)=f(x+6)~ and ~F(x)=g(x)+2~.

statement.p: State the basic function and the transformations needed to graph ~~G(x)=\dfrac{1}{4}(x-3)^3.

answer.p: The basic function is ~f(x)=x^3~. Then ~g(x)=f(x-3)~ and ~F(x)=\dfrac{1}{4}g(x)~.
